As the Affordable Care Act was rolling out, we peppered NPR's Julie Rovner with questions.
Many came from you, our listeners - questions about who's eligible for what, and how to enroll.
Now that the law's in effect, the question is how well it's working.The Obama administration says an estimated 7.5 million people have signed up through the health exchanges.
And preliminary surveys show declines in the percentage of Americans without coverage.
But as for how well the law is - or is not - meeting its goals, Julie says getting clear answers may take a while.
Among the things lots of people are asking are how many of those who've signed up have paid their premiums.
How many of them were uninsured before they signed up?
How big is the drop been in the number of uninsured people?
In some cases, the answers to these questions simply aren't knowable, or not knowable yet, says Linda Blumberg, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute in Washington.
You know, it's very challenging, and people want answers right away, and the best datasets that we have obviously come out with a lag.
Part of that is due to the enormous size and complexity of the health system and the law.
But it's also due to the fact that the insurance industry is mostly private and regulated by the states, says Robert Zirkelbach.
He's spokesman for the trade group America's Health Insurance Plans.
The impact that all of these changes are going to have on the marketplace are going to play out differently all across the country.
Simply looking at national data doesn't tell you what's going to happen in a particular market in a particular state.

If you're a man between the ages of 65 and 80, you should be getting regular prostate cancer screenings.
Now a new study says that if you or someone you know is diagnosed, waiting for treatment could be problematic.
Most cancer diagnoses come with an immediate call to action - chemotherapy, surgery or radiation - but prostate cancer can be slow moving.
And some doctors say it's better to wait; others, however, do not.
Findings from the report are raising eyebrows within the medical community.
What does it all mean for African-American men who die from prostate cancer more than any other group?
NPR's Tony Cox talked to a medical expert who puts the science in perspective.
Later, a congressman discusses what he's doing to address the disparity.

But first, more on the controversial report published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.. Tony spoke with the study's leading author, Dr. Yu-Ning Wong of the Fox Chase Center in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
We used data from linked senior Medicare databases, which are - which contain information on patients who were diagnosed and treated with prostate cancer from 1991 to 1999.

And we looked up the men who received treatment of either radiation therapy or surgery during the first six months past their treatment, compared to patients who did not receive treatment during this time interval.
And we found that patients who received treatment lived longer than the patients who were observed.

One of the caveats of an observational study is that we know that patients who received treatment may be inherently different than the patients who did not receive active treatments, but we did find out the benefit of treatment did persist after adjusting for all the observed potential differences.
Why are some patients advised to wait instead of undergoing treatment right away after they've been diagnosed?
The benefit of treatment in elderly patients has been a subject of significant controversy.
I think watchful waiting has been considered the least harmful option for patients since many prostate cancers can be slow grown and never be destined to cause disease or symptoms.
Unfortunately, some patients do die of prostate cancer.
So in patients who are healthy and have a prolonged life expectancy - still may be a very reasonable treatment option.
Was it your belief that watchful waiting, or the issues surrounding the efficacy of that, is that what led you to conduct this study?

And Vioxx looked safer than it really was.

Weinblatt received an initial check for $15,000 a few weeks later.
In a written statement to NPR, Michael Weinblatt defended the consulting contract and his work on the DSMB.
His words are read by an actor.
Unidentified Man #3: I deeply resent the suggestion that there was any conflict of interest between my brief service on the advisory board and my work as chair of the VIGOR DSMB.
